title: Hick's Law
description: More options leads to harder decisions.

title: Confirmation Bias
description: People look for evidence that confirms what they think.

title: Priming
description: Previous stimuli influence users' decision.

title: Cognitive Load
description: Total amount of mental effort that is required to complete a task.

title: Anchoring Bias
description: Users rely heavily on the first piece of information they see.

title: Nudge
description: Subtle hints can affect users' decisions.

title: Progressive Disclosure
description: Users are less overwhelmed if they're exposed to complex features later.

title: Fitts's Law
description: Large and close elements are easier to interact with.

title: Attentional Bias
description: Users' thoughts filter what they pay attention to.

title: Empathy Gap
description: People underestimate how much emotions influence user behaviors.

title: Visual Anchors
description: Elements used to guide users' eyes.

title: Von Restorff Effect
description: People notice items that stand out more.

title: Visual Hierarchy
description: The order in which people perceive what they see.

title: Selective Attention
description: People filter out things from their environment when in focus.

title: Survivorship Bias
description: People neglect things that don't make it past a selection process.

title: Banner Blindness
description: Users tune out the stuff they get repeatedly exposed to.

title: Juxtaposition
description: Elements that are close and similar are perceived as a single unit.

title: Signifiers
description: Elements that communicate what they will do.

title: Contrast
description: Users' attention is drawn to higher visual weights.

title: External Trigger
description: When the information on what to do next is within the prompt itself.

title: Decoy Effect
description: Create a new option that's easy to discard.

title: Centre-Stage Effect
description: People tend to choose the middle option in a set of items.

title: Framing
description: The way information is presented affects how users make decisions.

title: Law of Proximity
description: Elements close to each other are usually considered related.

title: Tesler's Law
description: If you simplify too much, you'll transfer some complexity to the users.

title: Spark Effect
description: Users are more likely to take action when the effort is small.

title: Feedback Loop
description: When users take action, feedback communicates what happened.

title: Expectations Bias
description: People tend to be influenced by their own expectations.

title: Aesthetic-Usability Effect
description: People perceive designs with great aesthetics as easier to use.

title: Social Proof
description: Users adapt their behaviors based on what others do.

title: Scarcity
description: People value things more when they're in limited supply.

title: Curiosity Gap
description: Users have a desire to seek out missing information.

title: Mental Model
description: Users have a preconceived opinion of how things work.

title: Familiarity Bias
description: People prefer familiar experiences.

title: Halo Effect
description: People judge things (or people) based on their feelings towards one trait.

title: Miller’s Law
description: Users can only keep 7±2 items in their working memory.

title: Unit Bias
description: One unit of something feels like the optimal amount.

title: Flow State
description: Being fully immersed and focused on a task.

title: Skeuomorphism
description: Users adapt more easily to things that look like real-world objects.

title: Singularity Effect
description: Users care disproportionately about an individual as compared to a group.

title: Reciprocity
description: People feel the need to reciprocate when they receive something.

title: Authority Bias
description: Users attribute more importance to the opinion of an authority figure.

title: Pseudo-Set Framing
description: Tasks that are part of a group are more tempting to complete.

title: Variable Reward
description: People especially enjoy unexpected rewards.

title: Group Attractiveness Effect
description: Individual items seem more attractive when presented in a group.

title: Curse of Knowledge
description: Not realizing that people don't have the same level of knowledge.

title: Aha! moment
description: When new users first realize the value of your product.

title: Self-Initiated Triggers
description: Users are more likely to interact with prompts they setup for themselves.

title: Survey Bias
description: Users tend to skew survey answers towards what's socially acceptable.

title: Cognitive Dissonance
description: It's painful to hold two opposing ideas in our mind.

title: Goal Gradient Effect
description: Motivation increases as users get closer to their goal.

title: Feedforward
description: When users know what to expect before they take action.

title: Occam’s Razor
description: Simple solutions are often better than the more complex ones.

title: Noble Edge Effect
description: Users tend to prefer socially responsible companies.

title: Hawthorne Effect
description: Users change their behavior when they know they are being observed.

title: Hindsight Bias
description: People overestimate their ability to predict outcomes after the fact.

title: Law of Similarity
description: Users perceive a relationship between elements that look similar.

title: Law of Prägnanz
description: Users interpret ambiguous images in a simpler and more complete form.

title: Streisand Effect
description: When trying to censor information ends up increasing awareness of that information.

title: Spotlight Effect
description: People tend to believe they are being noticed more than they really are.

title: Fresh Start Effect
description: Users are more likely to take action if there's a feeling of new beginnings.

title: Labor Illusion
description: People value things more when they see the work behind them.

title: Default Bias
description: Users tend not to change an established behavior.

title: Investment Loops
description: When users invest themselves, they're more likely to come back.

title: Loss Aversion
description: People prefer to avoid losses more than earning equivalent gains.

title: Commitment & Consistency
description: Users tend to be consistent with their previous actions.

title: Sunk Cost Effect
description: Users are reluctant to pull out of something they're invested in.

title: Decision Fatigue
description: Making a lot of decisions lowers users' ability to make rational ones.

title: Reactance
description: Users are less likely to adopt a behavior when they feel forced.

title: Observer-Expectancy Effect
description: When researchers' biases influence the participants of an experiment.

title: Weber's Law
description: Users adapt better to small incremental changes.

title: Law of the Instrument
description: If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail.

title: Temptation Bundling
description: Hard tasks are less scary when coupled with something users desire.

title: Parkinson’s Law
description: The time required to complete a task will take as much time as allowed.

title: Dunning-Kruger Effect
description: People tend to overestimate their skills when they don't know much.

title: Affect Heuristic
description: People's current emotions cloud and influence their judgment.

title: Hyperbolic Discounting
description: People tend to prioritize immediate benefits over bigger future gains.

title: Cashless Effect
description: People spend more when they can't actually see the money.

title: Chronoception
description: People's perception of time is subjective.

title: Self-serving bias
description: People take credits for positive events and blame others if negative.

title: Pareto Principle
description: Roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes.

title: Discoverability
description: The ease with which users can discover your features.

title: Backfire Effect
description: When people's convictions are challenged, their beliefs get stronger.

title: False Consensus Effect
description: People overestimate how much other people agree with them.

title: Bandwagon Effect
description: Users tend to adopt beliefs in proportion of others who have already done so.

title: Barnum-Forer Effect
description: When you believe generic personality descriptions apply specifically to you.

title: Second-Order Effect
description: The consequences of the consequences of actions.

title: IKEA Effect
description: When user partially create something, they value it way more.

title: Planning Fallacy
description: People tend to underestimate how much time a task will take.

title: Provide Exit Points
description: Invite users to leave your app at the right moment.

title: Peak-End Rule
description: People judge an experience by its peak and how it ends.

title: Sensory Appeal
description: Users engage more with things appealing to multiple senses.

title: Zeigarnik Effect
description: People remember incomplete tasks better than completed ones.

title: Endowment Effect
description: Users value something more if they feel it's theirs.

title: Chunking
description: People remember grouped information better.

title: Picture Superiority Effect
description: People remember pictures better than words.

title: Method of Loci
description: People remember things more when they're associated with a location.

title: Shaping
description: Incrementally reinforcing actions to get closer to a target behavior.

title: Delighters
description: People remember more unexpected and playful pleasures.

title: Internal Trigger
description: When users are prompted to take action based on a memory.

title: Recognition Over Recall
description: It's easier to recognize things than recall them from memory.

title: Storytelling Effect
description: People remember stories better than facts alone.

title: Negativity Bias
description: Users recall negative events more than positive ones.

title: Availability Heuristic
description: Users favor recent and available information over past information.

title: Spacing Effect
description: People learn more effectively when study sessions are spaced out.

title: Serial Position Effect
description: It's easier for users to recall the first and last items of a list.
